Main Suction Accumulator
The purpose of the main suction accumulator is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The main suction accumulator receives vapor from the flooded accumulators and separates any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Liquid in the main suction accumulator drains by gravity into the liquid transfer vessel. The main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the main suction accumulator contains low pressure vapor ammonia.

Liquid Transfer Vessel
The purpose of the liquid transfer vessel is to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrigeration system back to the high pressure receiver. The liquid transfer vessel receives liquid from the main suction accumulator. Once the liquid level in the liquid transfer vessel reaches the float switch, the three way solenoid valve is energized for a period of time causing the liquid transfer vessel to become subject to high pressure and allowing the liquid to drain by gravity into the high pressure receiver. Under normal conditions the liquid transfer vessel can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.

Compressors
The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporator to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the main suction accumulator and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal cond

itions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.

Evaporative Condenser
The purpose of the evaporative condenser is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphere. The evaporative condenser receives high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supplies high pressure liquid to the thermosyphon vessel. The condenser uses air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condenser contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Thermosyphon Vessel
The purpose of the thermosyphon vessel is to provide a supply of liquid ammonia necessary to cool the oil in the compressors. The thermosyphon vessel receives high pressure liquid from the condenser and supplies high pressure liquid to the thermosyphon oil cooler on each screw compressor. Excess liquid in the thermosyphon vessel is piped to the  high pressure receiver. High pressure ammonia vapor formed in each oil cooler is returned to the thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the thermosyphon vessel contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Oil Coolers
The purpose of the oil coolers is to remove heat from the oil being circulated through it. The oil coolers receive liquid from the thermosyphon vessel. High pressure liquid and vapor exits the oil coolers and is returned to the thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the oil coolers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

There are two ammonia sensors and a pressure transducer installed at Bravante Produce. The machinery room detection system is interlocked with the refrigeration system controls as follows:

1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Bravante Produce has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 Bravante Produce, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Bravante Produce has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name          | Process Chemical          | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Ammonia Refrigeration   Anhydrous Ammonia           13,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2.

Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Description

Bravante Produce operates a commercial cold storage for citrus and table grapes in Reedley, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:
(3) Storage Rooms
(1) Precool Rooms
(1) Hallways
(1) Loading Dock
(3) Degreening Rooms

Facility Location
Bravante Produce is located at 1356 S Buttonwillow Ave, Reedley, CA 93654. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver is 36.584579, -119.429404. The facility is located approximately 8 miles east of state highway 99 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agriculture land.

Flood Hazards
According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area of minimal flood hazard".

Seismic Susceptibility
Bravante Produce is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Bravante Produce has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.

Description of Covered Process

Flooded System

The refrigerated areas are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.

Most control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly above the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:

Process Chemistry
The refrigeration system employed at Bravante Produce is configured for flooded operation. The function and thermodynamics of each major component type in the system is summarized below:

High Pressure Receiver
The purpose of the high pressure receiver is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration system. The high pressure receiver receives high pressure liquid from the thermosyphon vessel and supplies high pressure liquid to each zone of refrigeration. The high pressure receiver is also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. The high pressure receiver is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receiver contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Flooded Accumulators
The purpose of each flooded accumulator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the evaporators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure l

iquid as it enters the vessel. The flooded accumulators supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated evaporators. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the flooded accumulators to allow only the vapor to be returned to the main suction accumulator. Under normal conditions, the flooded accumulators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Air-Cooling Evaporators (Flooded)
The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the flooded accumulators. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Air-Cooling Evaporators (Direct Expansion)
The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the high pressure receiver. Each evaporator is equipped with an expansion valve which reduces the pressure and temperature of the liquid as it enters the evaporator. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold li

the auto-dialer will notify facility personnel;
If the ammonia concentration exceeds 75 ppm, emergency ventilation will be activated and the auto-dialer with notify 911;

The sample system is equipped with an ammonia detector, vacuum pump, and tubing which extends to the rooms where air is sampled. The vacuum pump is used to draw air through the tubing into the detector. On two minute intervals, the system toggles from one sample point to the next. The sample systems provide ammonia detection to non-machinery rooms as summarized below:
Main Electrical Room Sample System
Rooms 1-3
Precool Room
Loading Dock
Hallway
Degreening Rooms 1-3

If the sample system detects an ammonia concentration exceeding 25 ppm, the system will activate an alarm and notify plant personnel of the situation through the auto-dialer.
The relief vent pipe pressure transducer acts similar to that of an ammonia vent line sensor. It will notify the PLC of any changes in pressure triggered by an ammonia release from a pressure relief valve to the ammonia adsorption tank.

Emergency Control Box
The Emergency Control Box (ECB) is installed on the south wall of the machinery room and contains three (3) valves.
Valve #1: High Side Discharge Valve
Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve
Valve #3: High to Low Pressure Control Valve
Opening Valve #1 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system. Opening Valve #2 will evacuate the process through the low pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #3 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system. 

All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summarized below:
Each relief valve has a set pressure equal to or less than the MAWP of the equipment that the relief valve protects;
Each relief valve has a capacity which meets or exceeds the requi

rement of ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A §15.3.8;
All relief valves are connected to a common manifold which terminates into the ammonia diffusion tank;

Ammonia Adsorption Tank
The refrigeration system is equipped with an ammonia adsorption tank which mitigates most of the hazards associated with a relief valve lifting. The relief valve discharge piping is terminated at the bottom of the ammonia adsorption tank. The ammonia adsorption tank is 10' dia. 22' high (12,950 gallon capacity). At a water level of 15'-0", the tank contains 8,812 gallons of water which exceeds the quantity recommended by ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A §15.5.3 which is based on 1 gallon of water per pound of ammonia released through the largest relief valve in the system in 60 minutes. Under normal conditions, the ammonia adsorption tank contains water.

Screw Compressor Safety Devices
Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:
High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.
Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.
Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.
High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.
Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint.
Discharge Temperature Cutout - The high discharge temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.

High Level Float S

witch
The main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high liquid level in the vessel. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors.

Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valve (King Valve)
The high pressure receiver is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system.

Emergency Refrigeration Switches (E-Stops)
Each entrance to the machinery room is equipped with an emergency refrigeration switch (e-stop) that controls power to the refrigeration machinery inside the machinery room. The switches can be activated in an emergency using the hammer next to the switch to break the switch glass.

Process Classification
The ammonia refrigeration system at Bravante Produce consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Bravante Produce is treated as a single process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Bravante Produce has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders.
 
1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Bravante Produce facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 13,000 lbs. It is extremely important that this pr

ocess is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

Bravante Produce has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Bravante Produce's emergency response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR §3220
- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR §1910.38 

Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Bravante Produce has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Bravante Produce continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.
By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Bravante Produce's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Bravante Produce's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Bravante Produce

has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Bravante Produce has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Bravante Produce now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Bravante Produce employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Bravante Produce will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
